bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, September 20, 1940

div1.p: Andrus comments on the U.S. Army and his health. He also mentions Lambert's problems with his pension.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Albert E. Truby, September 20, 1940
div1.opener:
JHAndrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
9-20-40
FROM GEN. ALBERT E. TRUBY
Dear General:
div1.p:
It is nice to know that you remember me and that you are in-
terested in my welfare. I have often thought of you -
wondered if you were still on the coast and whether you have
found it possible to occupy your retirement pleasantly.

Recently - since our rulers and the public have become Army-
conscious - I have speculated as to the liklihood of your
being called back into active service.

Incidentally, I become highly incensed when I read of troops,
on maneuvers, using stove pipes for machine guns and trucks
as tanks and think of the millions that have been squandered
for leaf-raking and boondoggling.

Of course I don't blame the Army for our deplorable lack of
preparedness. The Army has probably done the best it could
with the funds available. The blame, in my humble opinion,
must be placed on our legislators for regulating their official
acts by the probable effect on their reelection.

Please excuse my getting off base. I watch developments so
intently and am so concerned about what may happen that I am
prone to forget that that what I think is not of the slightest
interest to anyone...

Yes, I'm still alive. And still in bed. I have been
bedfast since March first, 1932. Was at Walter Reed Hos-
pital from May 13 until October sixth, 1932 and, since then,
have been at home.

In all this time I have been taken care of by my wife who has
made a virtual prisoner of herself. My son, a graduate of
Hahnemann Medical College, practices at this address and has
given me excellent care.

I am obliged to lay prone. Any weight on my spine - even
sitting up in bed - brings back the paralysis. I can turn
in bed, have the use of my arms and legs, have a good appetite
and weigh more now than when I went to bed.

When at Walter Reed I had quite a number of attacks of paroxysmal
tachycardia - one lasting 22 hours - but have been without an
attack for nearly a year.

The yellow fever annuity has been a godsend to me. If I
was constantly bedeviled by the thought that - in addition to
burdening my family with my care - I was a financial liability
I'm afraid it would have driven me crazy long ago.

As it is, my principal worry is that when I die the annuity
stops.

Do you remember Gust E. Lambert who was Dr. Ames' right hand
man at the yellow fever hospital? He has had several bills
in Congress to place him on the honor roll. On two or three
occasions his bill has passed the Senate only to be killed in
the House.

This year, again, the bill was up and reported favorably by the
House Committee on Military Affairs. When an attempt was
made to bring it before the House, for vote, on a unanimous
consent agreement, Representatives Hancock, Cole and Schaeffer
objected.

Lambert came from his home in Chicago to appear before a sub-
committee for a hearing. The night of the hearing his wife
fell at their hotel. The following day, his wife's condi-
tion was sufficiently improved so that he came to Camden to
see me. (Just for the day.)

Returning to Washington, he and his wife boarded a train for
Birmingham. His wife was stricken with a heart attack and
they left the train in Virginia where his wife died in a hos-
pital.

I feel very sorry for Lambert. He is badly crippeled with
arthritis and his eyesight is seriously impaired.

Have always felt that, had Major Reed lived until the bill was
passed creating the roll of honor and granting annuities, both
Dr. Ames and Lambert would have appeared on the list...

On the group photograph of Columbia Barracks Hospital personnel,
number 40 is John Colby. This completes the list...

I hope you will write again. Would like to know what you
think of world conditions and, especially, what you think of
the probability of our involvement.
With kindest regards and every good wish,
div1.closer:
Sincerely, J H Andrus General Albert E. Truby,
145 Laurel Street,
San Francisco, Calif.
